name: Business Architecture
description: Business capabilities, processes, and organizational structures

categories.name: Institutional Securities - Sales & Trading
categories.description: Capabilities supporting institutional securities, sales, and trading operations.

subcategories.name: Cash Equities
subcategories.description: Capabilities for cash equities trading and related services.

capabilities.name: Client Management Services
capabilities.definition: Services and processes for managing institutional client relationships, onboarding, and support.

maturityLevels.description: CRM system in place, some automation

capabilities.name: Sales & Distribution
capabilities.definition: Activities related to the distribution and sale of cash equity products to institutional clients.

capabilities.name: Modelling & Research Activities
capabilities.definition: Research, analytics, and quantitative modeling to support trading and investment decisions.

capabilities.name: Data & Analytics
capabilities.definition: Data management, analytics, and reporting for trading, client, and market insights.

capabilities.name: Front Office Risk
capabilities.definition: Risk management activities performed by the front office, including real-time risk assessment and controls.

capabilities.name: Transaction Processing Services
capabilities.definition: Processing, clearing, and settlement of cash equity transactions.

capabilities.name: Firm Risk & Cross Divisional Governance
capabilities.definition: Oversight, governance, and risk management across divisions and at the firm level.

capabilities.name: Operations
capabilities.definition: Operational support for trade lifecycle, reconciliations, and exception management.

capabilities.name: Finance
capabilities.definition: Financial management, reporting, and control for cash equities trading.

name: Application Architecture
description: Software applications and their interactions within the enterprise

categories.name: Application Engineering
categories.description: Core business applications and engineering tools for application functionality and logic

subcategories.name: Enterprise Applications
subcategories.description: Core business applications and systems

capabilities.name: Enterprise Resource Planning
capabilities.definition: Integrated software platform managing core business processes
capabilities.description: Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) provides a unified suite of applications that streamline and automate critical business processes such as finance, procurement, supply chain, and human resources. ERP enables consistent data sharing, process efficiency, and real-time insights across the enterprise.

maturityLevels.description: Basic ERP in place for core functions

capabilities.name: Customer Relationship Management
capabilities.definition: Technology for managing customer interactions and relationships

capabilities.name: Business Intelligence
capabilities.definition: Analytics and reporting capabilities for data-driven decision making
capabilities.description: Business Intelligence (BI) enables organizations to transform raw data into actionable insights through reporting, dashboards, and interactive analytics. BI helps stakeholders monitor performance, identify trends, and make informed strategic decisions.

subcategories.name: Collaboration & Content
subcategories.description: Tools for team collaboration and content management

capabilities.name: Collaboration Tools
capabilities.definition: Platforms enabling team communication and collaboration
capabilities.description: Collaboration Tools facilitate effective communication, information sharing, and teamwork within and across organizations. These tools enhance productivity, especially in distributed or hybrid work environments.

capabilities.name: Content Management
capabilities.definition: Systems for creating, managing, and publishing digital content
capabilities.description: Content Management enables organizations to efficiently create, organize, store, and distribute digital content across channels. It ensures content consistency, brand integrity, and supports marketing and operational needs.

capabilities.name: Integration Platform
capabilities.definition: Middleware connecting disparate systems and applications
capabilities.description: An Integration Platform enables seamless data and process flow between different applications, systems, and services. It reduces complexity, improves agility, and supports both real-time and batch integrations across the enterprise.

subcategories.name: Orchestration & Logic
subcategories.description: Tools for modeling, executing, and monitoring business processes

capabilities.name: Workflow Orchestration
capabilities.definition: The ability to model, execute, and monitor multi-step business processes in an automated and maintainable way.
capabilities.description: Workflow orchestration tools allow developers and operations teams to encode business logic as a sequence of tasks or state machines. These tools support retry logic, timeouts, parallelism, and integration across APIs or microservices.

capabilities.name: Business Rules Engine
capabilities.definition: The ability to manage and execute rule-based logic separately from application code.
capabilities.description: Business rules engines allow non-developers or analysts to define policies, thresholds, or conditional behaviors through declarative logic. These rules are maintained outside the application codebase and can be updated independently.

categories.name: Application Interaction
categories.description: Tools for user interaction, UI behavior, user session handling, and presentation orchestration

subcategories.name: Application Composition
subcategories.description: Tools for building and composing applications from independent components

capabilities.name: Modular Frontend Frameworks
capabilities.definition: The ability to compose frontends from independently developed and deployable micro frontends or components.
capabilities.description: Modular frontend frameworks allow teams to build applications that are split across multiple domains or teams, while maintaining a cohesive user experience. Each module can be deployed independently and upgraded without affecting the entire frontend.

capabilities.name: Plugin Frameworks
capabilities.definition: The capability to dynamically extend an applicationâ€™s features through independently developed modules or plugins.
capabilities.description: Plugin frameworks provide an interface through which third parties or internal developers can add new functionality without modifying the core codebase. Common in extensible apps such as editors, platforms, and developer tools.

subcategories.name: State & Navigation
subcategories.description: Tools for managing and navigating application state

capabilities.name: State Management
capabilities.definition: The capability to manage, share, and persist application state across components, views, or services.
capabilities.description: State management libraries provide centralized or scoped approaches to handle dynamic data such as user inputs, responses, or derived values. These are especially important in reactive and SPAs where data must flow between UI layers and services.

subcategories.name: Form & Content Systems
subcategories.description: Tools for building and managing forms and content systems

capabilities.name: Form Builders
capabilities.definition: The capability to build and render dynamic, schema-driven forms at runtime.
capabilities.description: Form builders enable developers or non-technical users to create and manage forms for data entry, validation, and submission. They support dynamic schemas, conditional logic, and integrations with backend APIs.
benefits: Better UX for complex input flows

categories.name: Application Integration
categories.description: Integration and collaboration tools for applications

subcategories.name: Messaging Patterns
subcategories.description: Tools for managing and orchestrating integration flows

capabilities.name: Message Routing
capabilities.definition: The capability to direct messages to the correct processing component or service based on content or metadata.
capabilities.description: This includes routing patterns such as Content-Based Router, Routing Slip, and Recipient List that guide message delivery dynamically based on message properties.

capabilities.name: Message Transformation
capabilities.definition: The capability to modify or translate messages between formats, protocols, or structures as they move between systems.
capabilities.description: This includes Content Enricher, Message Translator, and Canonical Data Model patterns used to harmonize data between services.

capabilities.name: Messaging Endpoints
capabilities.definition: The capability to connect services or applications via reusable, reliable messaging interfaces.
capabilities.description: Includes endpoint patterns such as Inbound/Outbound Channel Adapters and Durable Subscribers that abstract communication protocols.

subcategories.name: Integration Control Flow
subcategories.description: Tools for managing and orchestrating integration flows

capabilities.name: Aggregator Pattern
capabilities.definition: The capability to combine messages or events from multiple sources into a single, unified message.
capabilities.description: Used when multiple sources contribute partial data that needs to be correlated and emitted as a complete message.

capabilities.name: Splitter Pattern
capabilities.definition: The ability to break a single composite message into multiple sub-messages for parallel or independent processing.
capabilities.description: Useful for breaking down payloads into units of work that can be handled individually, e.g., batch records.

capabilities.name: Resequencer Pattern
capabilities.definition: The capability to reorder messages into a defined sequence before forwarding to the next component.
capabilities.description: Critical for maintaining order when messages arrive out of sequence due to retries, async processing, or distributed systems.

subcategories.name: Event-Driven Architecture
subcategories.description: Tools for building event-driven architectures

capabilities.name: Event Stream Processing
capabilities.definition: The capability to continuously capture, analyze, and respond to events as they occur in real time.
capabilities.description: Supports near real-time applications by enabling transformation, filtering, enrichment, and routing of event data as it flows through the system. Often implemented using stream processing engines.

capabilities.name: Event Replay & Retention
capabilities.definition: The capability to store and replay historical events to reprocess, debug, or audit application behavior.
capabilities.description: Useful in event-sourced systems or for restoring state by replaying a durable log of past events. Enables recovery, compliance, and new service onboarding with historical data.

capabilities.name: Event Contracts & Schemas
capabilities.definition: The capability to define, manage, and evolve structured formats and agreements for event payloads.
capabilities.description: Supports safe evolution and interoperability in distributed systems by providing versioned schemas and validation. Encourages reuse and reduces tight coupling between publishers and consumers.

name: Data Architecture
description: Data assets, storage, and management across the organization

capabilities.name: Data Warehousing
capabilities.definition: Centralized repository for storing and analyzing large volumes of data

capabilities.name: Real-time Analytics
capabilities.definition: Processing and analyzing data as it arrives for immediate insights

categories.name: Data Management
categories.description: Core data management and governance capabilities

capabilities.name: Master Data Management
capabilities.definition: Unified, consistent view of critical business data across systems

capabilities.name: Data Governance
capabilities.definition: Framework for managing data availability, usability, and security

capabilities.name: Data Lake
capabilities.definition: Storage repository for raw data in native format until needed

capabilities.name: Backup & Recovery
capabilities.definition: Protection and restoration of critical business data

name: Infrastructure Architecture
description: Physical and virtual infrastructure supporting business operations

subcategories.name: Application Development
subcategories.description: Tools and processes for developing applications

capabilities.name: Development Tools
capabilities.definition: Environments and platforms used to write, build, and test code
capabilities.description: Development tools support the creation and maintenance of software by providing code editing, debugging, and build environments. These tools enhance developer productivity and ensure code quality throughout the development lifecycle.

capabilities.name: Code Analysis
capabilities.definition: Automated tools for evaluating code quality, security, and compliance
capabilities.description: Code analysis tools perform static and dynamic assessments of source code to identify bugs, vulnerabilities, or policy violations early in the development lifecycle. This enhances software maintainability and security.

capabilities.name: Infrastructure as Code
capabilities.definition: Automated infrastructure provisioning using declarative or scripted configuration
capabilities.description: Infrastructure as Code enables teams to manage and provision infrastructure using code, promoting repeatability, scalability, and integration with CI/CD pipelines.

subcategories.name: Application Support & Operations
subcategories.description: Tools for deploying, monitoring, and operating applications

capabilities.name: Packaging & Distribution
capabilities.definition: Storage and distribution of build artifacts and packages
capabilities.description: This capability supports artifact management by storing, versioning, and distributing compiled software, libraries, and container images across environments.

capabilities.name: Release Automation
capabilities.definition: Tools that automate application deployment and release management
capabilities.description: Release automation enables teams to reliably and repeatedly deploy applications across environments using GitOps or similar pipelines.

capabilities.name: Monitoring & Observability
capabilities.definition: Tools and processes for measuring, analyzing, and visualizing system performance and health
capabilities.description: This capability allows organizations to detect, diagnose, and resolve issues using telemetry data such as logs, metrics, and traces.

subcategories.name: AI, ML & Automation
subcategories.description: Artificial intelligence and machine learning platforms

capabilities.name: AI, ML & Automation
capabilities.definition: Technologies that enable intelligent decision-making and process automation
capabilities.description: This capability supports automation of tasks and insights generation using artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies.

subcategories.name: Database
subcategories.description: Database platforms and services

capabilities.name: Document Store
capabilities.definition: Non-relational databases optimized for semi-structured document storage
capabilities.description: Document stores are designed to store, retrieve, and manage data in document-oriented formats such as JSON or BSON, enabling flexibility in schema and performance for content-heavy applications.

capabilities.name: OLTP & Capture
capabilities.definition: Databases and systems optimized for online transaction processing
capabilities.description: OLTP systems support high-throughput transactional workloads with rapid reads and writes, ensuring data integrity and fast response times for business-critical applications.

subcategories.name: Data Platform
subcategories.description: Data processing and analytics platforms

capabilities.name: Data Caching
capabilities.definition: Temporary storage for frequently accessed data to improve performance
capabilities.description: Data caching enables faster data retrieval by storing frequently used data closer to the application layer, reducing latency and load on primary databases.

capabilities.name: Data Integration
capabilities.definition: The ability to combine data from different sources, formats, or systems into a unified view or pipeline
capabilities.description: Data Integration capabilities allow systems to connect, transform, and synchronize information across a wide variety of platforms. This includes both batch ETL and real-time data flows, and supports use cases ranging from business intelligence to cross-platform orchestration.

capabilities.name: Reactive Queries
capabilities.definition: Automatically re-running queries or data-fetching logic in response to changes in application or external state
capabilities.description: Reactive query systems allow applications to respond in real-time to changes in inputs, filters, cache state, or user interactions. This is increasingly used in frontend and fullstack development for performance-sensitive and UX-optimized applications.

subcategories.name: Business Process Management
subcategories.description: Business process automation and management

capabilities.name: Process Automation
capabilities.definition: Digital automation of business workflows and repetitive tasks
capabilities.description: Process automation tools streamline operations by enabling users to define and execute workflows, reducing manual errors and improving scalability.

subcategories.name: Middleware
subcategories.description: Integration and communication middleware

capabilities.name: Messaging
capabilities.definition: Asynchronous communication between distributed systems
capabilities.description: Messaging platforms support decoupled service communication through message brokers and queues, enabling scalability, fault tolerance, and event-driven architecture.

capabilities.name: Web Hosting
capabilities.definition: Serving web applications and content over the internet
capabilities.description: Web hosting platforms enable the deployment and operation of web-based applications, APIs, and static content to end users.

capabilities.name: Workload Scheduling
capabilities.definition: Scheduling and automation of batch jobs and background processes
capabilities.description: Workload schedulers coordinate and manage the execution of jobs based on dependencies and timing rules, ensuring resource efficiency and job completion.

categories.name: Storage
categories.description: Storage systems and data persistence solutions

subcategories.name: Offline Storage
subcategories.description: Long-term storage and archival solutions

capabilities.name: Archive
capabilities.definition: Long-term storage of data for compliance and retrieval
capabilities.description: Archiving solutions preserve historical data that must be retained for legal, regulatory, or business purposes while ensuring secure and efficient retrieval.

capabilities.name: Backup
capabilities.definition: Replication of data for recovery and protection
capabilities.description: Backup systems safeguard critical data by creating copies stored separately to enable recovery in the event of failure, corruption, or disaster.

subcategories.name: Logical Compute
subcategories.description: Serverless and function-based computing

capabilities.name: Logical Compute
capabilities.definition: Abstracted compute environments for running applications without managing servers
capabilities.description: Logical compute refers to serverless or function-based compute environments that abstract infrastructure management, allowing developers to focus on application logic.

subcategories.name: Mainframe
subcategories.description: Enterprise mainframe computing platforms

capabilities.name: Mainframe
capabilities.definition: Large-scale computing platforms supporting critical enterprise applications
capabilities.description: Mainframes run batch and transaction processing workloads with high reliability, scalability, and security. They are essential for industries like banking and insurance.

subcategories.name: Servers
subcategories.description: Physical and virtual server infrastructure

capabilities.name: Servers
capabilities.definition: Physical and virtual machines hosting applications and services
capabilities.description: Servers provide the compute resources required to run enterprise workloads. They may be physical machines, virtualized environments, or part of hybrid infrastructure.

subcategories.name: IT Management
subcategories.description: IT service management and operations

capabilities.name: IT Management
capabilities.definition: Tools and practices for managing IT assets, incidents, and services
capabilities.description: IT management tools support ITSM practices such as service requests, change management, and incident resolution, enhancing operational efficiency and user support.

name: Security Architecture
description: Security controls, policies, and technologies protecting the enterprise

capabilities.name: Identity & Access Management
capabilities.definition: Framework for managing digital identities and access permissions

capabilities.name: Endpoint Protection
capabilities.definition: Security solutions protecting end-user devices and endpoints

capabilities.name: Network Security
capabilities.definition: Technologies protecting network infrastructure from threats

capabilities.name: Security Monitoring
capabilities.definition: Continuous monitoring and analysis of security events

capabilities.name: Data Protection
capabilities.definition: Technologies and processes protecting sensitive data

capabilities.name: Vulnerability Management
capabilities.definition: Process of identifying and remediating security vulnerabilities
